issue.title: Conda-build generates package with no functions
issue.body:
### Actual Behavior

Hi guys,

I've been trying to build a very simple conda package from the file TestFunctions.py.
```
| Temp/
	| - src/
        	| - TestFunctions.py
	| - meta.yaml
	| - bld.bat
	| - setup.py
```

However, conda-build generates a testpackage-0.0.1-0.tar.bz2 but with no functions.
(the tarball does not have the lib folder, just the info folder)

I've also tried some changes such as:
- using build.script and pip rather than setuptools
- using (1) build, host and run, (2) build and run and (3) host and run
- remove and recreate the conda env
- reinstall conda

But had no luck. 

From the docs and examples I've seen, it should have worked but it seems it's not creating the "temporary" conda environments (_build_env?) as expected.

### Expected Behavior

Conda-build should have generated a testpackage-0.0.1-py37-0.tar.bz2 with two functions: TestA and TestB.

### Steps to Reproduce

conda create --name Temp-dev-env --no-default-package python=3.7 conda-build m2-patch
conda activate Temp-dev-env

conda build .

##### src/TestFunctions.py

def TestB(x ,y):

```

##### meta.yaml

        # - pip

```

```

```

- using build.script and pip rather than setuptools

issue.title: Unable to force the Visual Studio 2017 compiler for a python 2.7.15 build of yt
issue.body:
Following an initial problem solved at #3872, I have built yt against python 2.7.15 using `conda build --python 2.7.15 yt` followed by `conda install --use-local yt`.

However, I realised that `conda build` compiled yt's python 2.7.15 using Visual Studio 2008, when I need it to be compiled with Visual Studio 2017 (to be compatible with the python 2.7.15 running in Houdini, into which I want to import yt).

I therefore followed the instructions here:
```
https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda-build/en/latest/resources/compiler-tools.html#using-your-customized-compiler-package-with-conda-build-3
```

I edited the `conda_build_config.yaml` inside `C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\pkgs\yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0\info\recipe` to replace `c_compiler: vs2008 ` with `c_compiler: vs2017` and `cxx_compiler: vs2008 ` with `cxx_compiler: vs2017` and `vc: '9'` with `vc: '14.16'`.

However, when I then ran `conda build --python 2.7.15 yt`, I noticed the following messages during the build:
```
%SRC_DIR%>set "vc=9"
%SRC_DIR%>set "cxx_compiler=vs2008"
%SRC_DIR%>echo "Found VS2008 at"
"Found VS2008 at"
%SRC_DIR%>echo "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 9.0\Common7\IDE\"
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 9.0\Common7\IDE\"
%SRC_DIR%>SET "VS_VERSION=9.0"
%SRC_DIR%>SET "VS_MAJOR=9"
%SRC_DIR%>SET "VS_YEAR=2008"

```
So, the build was using `Visual Studio 2008` rather than the `Visual Studio 2017` that I specified in the `conda_build_config.yaml` edits.

I'm obviously doing something wrong but I don't know what!  

During the build, I've noticed that the entire `yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0` directory in `C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\pkgs` disappears and then is overwritten with a fresh version.  Inside that, the `conda_build_config.yaml` in `C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\pkgs\yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0\info\recipe` has reverted back to its original Visual Studio 2008 settings.

I don't know how to stop that happening.  

I'm not even sure how `yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0` gets into `C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\pkgs` in the first place.  I've tried deleting it prior to restarting my sequence of commands leading up to `conda build` again and have noticed that it reappears when I install prerequisite dependencies:
```
conda install -c conda-forge cython git sympy ipython numpy matplotlib netCDF4
```
For some reason, yt is also getting installed with these, even though it's not specified.  I don't know why.  It might be because of something I've done way back and now forgotten...

The overwriting of `yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0` with a fresh version seems to be wiping out the `conda_build_config.yaml` edits, preventing the compiler being changed from Visual Studio 2008 to Visual Studio 2017.

Alternatively, could the reversion to Visual Studio 2008 be because I'm editing the wrong `conda_build_config.yaml` file?  But I can't find another one - for example, there's no yt package in my env's `.../Lib/site-packages.`  Or maybe I need to do an edit to my env's `meta.yaml` file as well as to the `conda_build_config.yaml`?

I'd appreciate your suggestions.

issue.title: The build_number could be a long too.
issue.body:
Very small tweak for something that we just encountered here.
We are using timestamps for the last number. On Windows10 + Python 3.6.10 this was giving issues due to that number being a long (instead of an int).

issue.title: Conda build fails to import cython and numpy
issue.body:
I'm trying to build `yt` from source against `python 2.7.15` using `conda skeleton` then `conda build`. I get an error: ``` ImportError: Could not import cython or numpy. Building yt from source requires cython and numpy to be installed. Please install these packages using the appropriate package manager for your python environment. ``` Both these packages are installed but for some reason conda can't import (or find?) them. issue.title: Conda build fails to import cython and numpy
issue.body:
I'm trying to build `yt` from source against `python 2.7.15` using `conda skeleton` then `conda build`. I get an error: ``` ImportError: Could not import cython or numpy. Building yt from source requires cython and numpy to be installed. Please install these packages using the appropriate package manager for your python environment. ``` Both these packages are installed but for some reason conda can't import (or find?) them. I've activated my virtual environment `myyt1` and cd'd to its directory: ``` (myyt1) PS C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\envs\myyt1> ``` Using `conda list` shows that cython and numpy are present:

issue.title: Conda build fails to import cython and numpy
issue.body:
I'm trying to build `yt` from source against `python 2.7.15` using `conda skeleton` then `conda build`. I get an error: ``` ImportError: Could not import cython or numpy. Building yt from source requires cython and numpy to be installed. Please install these packages using the appropriate package manager for your python environment. ``` Both these packages are installed but for some reason conda can't import (or find?) them. I've activated my virtual environment `myyt1` and cd'd to its directory: ``` (myyt1) PS C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\envs\myyt1> ``` Using `conda list` shows that cython and numpy are present:

issue.title: ENH: Validating Python package dependencies
issue.body: Much as `conda-build` provides checks on library linkages, it would be useful to have a test time check of Python packages that validates all dependencies are accounted for. This would be analogous to `pip check`, but ideally could be done without `pip` (or at least using `pip` from the `base` environment) so that dependencies like `pkg_resources` can be accounted for without pulling in `setuptools` (except as a package dependency).
